awd_titl_txt: PFI TT: Intelligent quality assurance and integration tool for sewer inspection data
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project is conduct quality monitoring of sewers for clear public benefit.  Current practices in handling data incompatibility and quality issues are manual and time-consuming. In addition, these practices are customized for individual projects, a process hard to adapt to different projects. Moreover, the sewer inspection data remains fragmented within the utilities due to the lack of proper data management solutions, which makes data less accessible for asset management. The envisioned technology will help to combine sewer inspection data with standard PACP (Pipeline Assessment Certification Program) format, ensure data quality, and integrate historical data for easy and secured access so that cost-effective asset management plans can be developed based on true conditions. Each utility could save up to 80% of the time (on the order of months) for manual data quality assurance. With accurate and accessible sewer condition data, it is anticipated that at least 20% (approximately $600 million) of the annual spending on pipe rehabilitation can be saved for the entire industry. More importantly, improved sewer infrastructure condition can greatly reduce gastrointestinal (GI) illness emergency room visits induced by sanitary sewer overflow events. 

The proposed project is to 1) develop an artificial intelligence (AI)-enabled algorithm to resolve data incompatibility issues to maintain data fidelity and facilitate data exchange among different software platforms; 2) establish a holistic AI-enabled methodological framework to automatically detect and treat data quality issues, including data records inconsistency, incompleteness, and duplicates, caused by the interruption of inspection operations due to pipe defects or human errors; and 3) standardize municipal utilities’ practices in managing sewer condition data using blockchain-enabled technologies. This PFI-TT project will tailor the emerging AI/machine learning and blockchain technologies to develop an efficient data format translation algorithm, effective data quality assurance framework, and a blockchain-enabled sewer data management tool, with the objective to save engineers’ effort in data processing and render them more time for engineering decision making.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

This project aimed to develop a data integration and quality assurance tool to enhance wastewater sewer infrastructure asset management. The tool was designed to help municipalities counteract the accelerated deterioration of aging sewer systems nationwide by promoting data-driven, proactive asset management strategies. This research addressed the following challenges facing the wastewater industry: 1) insufficient data interoperability among proprietary sewer inspection software platforms, 2) data quality issues due to human errors, and 3) data accessibility problems that hinder municipalities' effective decision-making. To overcome these challenges, the project leveraged artificial intelligence (AI) techniques and state-of-the-art data security measures to develop an integrated data management tool for sewer inspection data.

To address data interoperability issues in the industry, we developed AI algorithms to map various sewer inspection data formats to standard Pipeline Assessment Certification Program (PACP) data. The algorithm analyzes a data column and recommends the top-ranked standard PACP data fields based on calculated probabilities. A user interface was also developed to provide an AI-assisted data mapping tool, streamlining the process of converting different sewer inspection data formats to standard PACP data. Standardizing data will enhance municipalities' efficiency in utilizing sewer condition data for asset management planning, enabling them to make informed decisions regarding maintenance and rehabilitation efforts.

To improve data quality, we developed AI-driven models for missing data imputation and invalid record correction for sewer inspection data. The algorithm is capable of imputing missing information and correcting invalid records for certain pipe inspection records by detecting the pattern from other data records related to those corresponding pipes, ensuring information consistency.

Finally, to address the data accessibility issues, we developed a centralized GIS-based cloud-based sewer data management web application to ensure that municipalities can efficiently store, retrieve, and analyze sewer condition data, ultimately supporting proactive and cost-effective infrastructure maintenance. To ensure data security, multiple-layer data security measures that leveraged state-of-the-art data security practices have been implemented in the web application, which has significantly reduced the likelihood of malicious data tampering practices.

This project has the potential to transform the wastewater infrastructure industry. By improving data interoperability, quality, and accessibility, The developed tool is projected to save municipalities up to $600 million annually in sewer rehabilitation costs while reducing the risk of sewer overflows and associated public health hazards.

This project has supported two graduate research assistants, five undergraduate research assistants, and one postdoctoral researcher. They gained experience in artificial intelligence, civil infrastructure asset management, data analytics, database programming, and web application development, which significantly contributed to workforce development in these fields. The project has also fostered collaboration between academia and industry, promoting commercialization opportunities and future innovations. By advancing AI-enabled sewer asset management strategies, it has played a role in modernizing the nation’s wastewater infrastructure and supporting sustainable development. Furthermore, this project contributed to the creation of a start-up company to commercialize the intellectual property developed through this research.


Last Modified: 04/17/2025
Modified by: Yongwei Shan
